column1: The above posi(cid:415)on has been summarised in Mihindukulasuriya [supra] in the following
“Whilst  emphasising  that  (a)  the  ini(cid:415)al  burden  in  a  rei  vindica(cid:415)o  ac(cid:415)on  is  on  the
plain(cid:415)ﬀ to prove ownership of the property in suit and (b) the standard of proof in a
rei vindica(cid:415)o ac(cid:415)on is proof on a balance of probabili(cid:415)es, if the plain(cid:415)ﬀ in such an
ac(cid:415)on  has  “suﬃcient  (cid:415)tle”  or  “superior  (cid:415)tle”  or  “be(cid:425)er  (cid:415)tle”  than  that  of  the
defendant, the plain(cid:415)ﬀ shall succeed. No rule of  thumb can be laid down in what
circumstances  the  Court  shall  hold  that  the  plain(cid:415)ﬀ  has  discharged  his  burden.
Whether or not the plain(cid:415)ﬀ proved his (cid:415)tle shall be decided upon a considera(cid:415)on of
the totality of the evidence led in the case.”
